subject: Re: [junit] which jdk will work with JUnit on Redhat6.2?
msgSnippet: Someone just emailed me that I was looking at a known bug in the sun jvm. ... From: Joi Ellis  To:  Sent: Friday, January
messageBody:
Someone just emailed me that I was looking at a known bug in the sun jvm.


----- Original Message -----
From: "Joi Ellis" <joi@...>
To: <junit@egroups.com>
Sent: Friday, January 19, 2001 3:25 PM
Subject: Re: [junit] which jdk will work with JUnit on Redhat6.2?


> On Fri, 19 Jan 2001, Peter Bismuti wrote:
>
> > I don't think that any of these are the problem. My RH6.2 is out of the
> > box, meaning the original glibc and original X11 and runs on a laptop.
I've
> > tried two jdk1.2.2s, blackdown's and sun's and both have the same
problems.
>
> Which problems, specifically? That stack trace you posted from the Junit
> test suite itself? Or are there others?
>
> > What version of JUnit are you using?
>
> I'm using JUnit 3.2 right now. I have 3.3.1, and it runs, but I have to
> change code in many of my tests to deal with deleted classes and methods
> I'm using. :/
>
> I noticed the error you're getting, and I don't see how that can be blamed
> upon the JVM. You aren't getting a JVM core dump or anything, you're
getting
> JUnit failures. When I upgraded, I had to diddle with my scripts and
> IDE settings to change some classpaths.
>
> You might be running into differences in the reflection API, perhaps?
>
> --
> Joi Ellis Software Engineer
> Aravox Technologies joi@..., gyles19@...
>
> No matter what we think of Linux versus FreeBSD, etc., the one thing I
> really like about Linux is that it has Microsoft worried. Anything
> that kicks a monopoly in the pants has got to be good for something.
> - Chris Johnson
>
>
> To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
> junit-unsubscribe@egroups.com
>
>
